conversation_summary: Night, amber streetlights blur like wet paint. A drunk dial warps time into Assad’s bare morning room—tangled sheets, cracked wall mirror, ornate hand mirror that flashes his face softer, almost girl. Hall breathes dust; photos twitch when un-watched. Father looms, eyes blood-veined, voice cracked: “I reported him—back room of prayers and flags.” Key rattles; Assad enters, same frame but mouth now slick rose, eyelashes longer. Sofa creaks under two silent bodies; lipstick gleams like a fresh wound while the unasked question—when did you become her?—hovers like smoke no one dares exhale.
